lines: ﻿"Who are you?" a harsh voice demanded. Mango realized he was in a protected Teak forest. The Teaks stood tall and erect like soldiers at parade.
"Why have you come here?" asked another.

"Son, don't you know that this area is reserved for Teak. You'd better leave," an old Teak advised. Mango decided to leave the forest. He walked on and on but couldn't find water anywhere. He thought he would die of thirst.
He came across an old Fig tree. "Grandpa, where can I get water to drink?" he asked.
"What a silly question! You're a tree, aren't you? Push your feet deep into the ground. You'll get water. You don't need to go anywhere."
"But that'll take time. Isn't there a river nearby?"
"Oh! Then you'll have to wait till it rains."

Mango left him and walked on through the mist. Giddy with hunger and thirst, he stumbled against stones, bumped into other trees. They cursed, "Blind fool!" "Clumsy oaf!" "I say, look where you're going."
Soon the sun rose and once again the path was clearly visible. Mango was exhausted and sweaty but he walked on past the trees till he reached the top of a hill. There he stood, thirsting for water.
